Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectrometer
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program (MRI) and support from the Chemistry Research Instrumentation Program (CRIF), Professor Brant Kedrowski from the University of Wisconsin Oshkosh and colleagues William Wacholtz and Sheri Lense have acquired a 400 MHz NMR spectrometer. This spectrometer allows research in a variety of fields such as those that accelerate chemical reactions of significant economic importance, as well as to study of biologically relevant species. In general, Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the elucidation of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between molecules in solution or in the solid state. The results from these NMR studies have an impact in synthetic organic/inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry and biochemistry. This instrument is an integral part of teaching as well as research performed by undergraduate students via independent student research and traditional academic coursework as well as researchers from the University of Wisconsin at Green Bay.

The award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) developing synthetic methodologies and applications for non-natural sterically congested amino acids; (b) synthesizing and characterizing organometallic charge transfer complexes with applications for solar energy or optically active molecular switches; (c) synthesizing and studying organometallic catalysts for carbon dioxide reduction; (d) synthesizing a potent electron transport chain inhibiting molecule stigmatellin and its analogues; (e) developing materials for organic solar cell applications; (f) developing inexpensive photovoltaics for energy harvesting; (g) analyzing natural carotenoid pigments isolated from local bacteria; and (h) synthesizing and characterizing a phosphatase inhibitor analogue.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant provided funds to purchase a 400 MHz Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectrometer to enhance teaching and research at the University of Wisconsin Oshkosh, in Oshkosh WI.  The NMR spectrometer acquired through this grant is a state-of-the-art instrument that provides detailed information on the structure and behavior of matter by studying atomic nuclei, which are the cores of atoms. 

The NMR spectrometer has had a major positive impact on teaching in undergraduate chemistry laboratories at the University of Wisconsin Oshkosh.  In sophomore level organic chemistry courses, up to 100 students per semester analyze proton and carbon nuclei in samples they have prepared in lab using the spectrometer.  These include molecules that they have synthesized or unknown chemicals they have been challenged to identify through use of the instrument.  As an example, students complete a multistep synthesis of the molecule E-anethole, which gives the spice anise its distinctive smell, and analyze their products after each step.   Junior and senior level students get hands on experience operating the instrument, acquiring data, and solving more sophisticated chemical problems in advanced inorganic and interpretive spectroscopy courses.  These students are exposed to a wider palette of nuclei including fluorine, phosphorus, and platinum.  They are also trained to use more advanced capabilities of the spectrometer including two-dimensional NMR experiments to solve more challenging chemical characterization problems.  As an example, students use the spectrometer to study the structure and dynamic behavior of the antiviral drug ribavirin.   In addition to labs included in traditional courses, many students have also used the NMR spectrometer extensively in their undergraduate research projects at UW Oshkosh.  This high impact practice using modern instrumentation provides students with valuable experience that positions them well for graduate studies and careers in chemical industry after graduation. 

The NMR spectrometer has also had a major positive impact on the progress of chemical research projects at the University of Wisconsin Oshkosh.  One project enabled by the NMR spectrometer was the preparation of sterically congested amino acids, which are interesting because they can confer hydrolytic stability and alternative secondary structures when incorporated into peptides.  Another project that used the NMR spectrometer was the development of a three-step synthesis of the natural product E-anethole that was the basis for the new undergraduate laboratory experiment described in the previous paragraph.  Another project that utilized the instrument involved the synthesis and study of novel organometallic catalysts for carbon dioxide reduction.   Reducing carbon dioxide converts this greenhouse gas into a useful building block for other molecules.  Another project that was made possible by the NMR spectrometer was the development of a new undergraduate laboratory experiment that focuses on studying organoplatinum complexes.  Platinum complexes are important catalysts for many chemical processes, and this experiment gives students experience preparing them and studying their proton, carbon, and platinum atoms using the spectrometer.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This grant provided funds to purchase a 400 MHz Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectrometer to enhance teaching and research at the University of Wisconsin Oshkosh, in Oshkosh WI. The NMR spectrometer acquired through this grant is a state-of-the-art instrument that provides detailed information on the structure and behavior of matter by studying atomic nuclei, which are the cores of atoms. The NMR spectrometer has had a major positive impact on teaching in undergraduate chemistry laboratories at the University of Wisconsin Oshkosh. In sophomore level organic chemistry courses, up to 100 students per semester analyze proton and carbon nuclei in samples they have prepared in lab using the spectrometer. These include molecules that they have synthesized or unknown chemicals they have been challenged to identify through use of the instrument. As an example, students complete a multistep synthesis of the molecule E-anethole, which gives the spice anise its distinctive smell, and analyze their products after each step. Junior and senior level students get hands on experience operating the instrument, acquiring data, and solving more sophisticated chemical problems in advanced inorganic and interpretive spectroscopy courses. These students are exposed to a wider palette of nuclei including fluorine, phosphorus, and platinum. They are also trained to use more advanced capabilities of the spectrometer including two-dimensional NMR experiments to solve more challenging chemical characterization problems. As an example, students use the spectrometer to study the structure and dynamic behavior of the antiviral drug ribavirin. In addition to labs included in traditional courses, many students have also used the NMR spectrometer extensively in their undergraduate research projects at UW Oshkosh. This high impact practice using modern instrumentation provides students with valuable experience that positions them well for graduate studies and careers in chemical industry after graduation. The NMR spectrometer has also had a major positive impact on the progress of chemical research projects at the University of Wisconsin Oshkosh. One project enabled by the NMR spectrometer was the preparation of sterically congested amino acids, which are interesting because they can confer hydrolytic stability and alternative secondary structures when incorporated into peptides. Another project that used the NMR spectrometer was the development of a three-step synthesis of the natural product E-anethole that was the basis for the new undergraduate laboratory experiment described in the previous paragraph. Another project that utilized the instrument involved the synthesis and study of novel organometallic catalysts for carbon dioxide reduction. Reducing carbon dioxide converts this greenhouse gas into a useful building block for other molecules. Another project that was made possible by the NMR spectrometer was the development of a new undergraduate laboratory experiment that focuses on studying organoplatinum complexes. Platinum complexes are important catalysts for many chemical processes, and this experiment gives students experience preparing them and studying their proton, carbon, and platinum atoms using the spectrometer.
